headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to The Priceline Group's fourth quarter 2015 conference call.The Priceline Group would like to remind everyone that this call may contain forward-looking statements which are made pursuant to the Safe Harbor Provisions of the Private Securities
componenttext:
Welcome to The Priceline Group's fourth quarter 2015 conference call.
The Priceline Group would like to remind everyone that this call may contain forward-looking statements which are made pursuant to the Safe Harbor Provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance, and are subject to risks -- certain risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual results may differ materially from those expressed, implied or forecasted in any such forward-looking statements. Expressions of future goals or citations and similar expressions reflecting something other than historical fact are intended to identify forward-looking statements.
For a list of factors that could cause the group's actual results to differ materially from those described in the forward-looking statements, please refer to the Safe Harbor statement at the end of the group's earnings press release as well as the group's most recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Unless required by law, the The Priceline Group undertakes no obligation to update publicly any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A copy of the group's earnings press release, together with some accompanying financial and statistical supplement, is available in the for investors section of the Priceline Group's website, www.pricelinegroup.com.
And now I'd like to introduce The Priceline Group's speakers for this afternoon, Darren Huston, and Daniel Finnegan. Go ahead, gentlemen.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you. Welcome to The Priceline Group's fourth quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us before the market opened this morning in New York. I'm here in Amsterdam with Priceline Group CFO, Dan Finnegan. The group reported another solid
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you. Welcome to The Priceline Group's fourth quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us before the market opened this morning in New York. I'm here in Amsterdam with Priceline Group CFO, Dan Finnegan. 
The group reported another solid quarter with consolidated gross bookings of approximately $12 billion, up about 24% on a constant-currency basis or 13% [ph] year-over-year in U.S. dollars. Our customers booked accommodation reservations for over 99 million room nights in the quarter, up 27% year-over-year. 
Gross profit was up 12% or about 23% on a constant-currency basis. Adjusted EBITDA was also up 11% at $790 million. And finally, our non-GAAP earnings per share was $12.63 [ph], surpassing FactSet consensus estimates of $11.81 per share and our guidance for the quarter.
Now I'd like to take a moment and reflect back on our full-year results. Our customers made reservations for over $432 million room nights on Priceline Group platforms in 2015, over twice as many as our next biggest competitor. Despite the law of large numbers, we are organically grew this business up 25%, down only 3 percentage points from 2014's growth rate, and exited the year growing more quickly than we were growing when we entered it. The business was very profitable, generating $3.7 billion of adjusted EBITDA and a 42.6% non-GAAP operating profit margin.
I believe that the solid performance in 2015 and many consecutive years and strong growth and profitability have been made possible by competitive advantages we have developed through the skill and hard work of our people around the world. 
Our capabilities in skill and partner acquisition, customer experience and efficient demand generation, plus our large installed base of accommodations and loyal travelers, give The Priceline Group a competitive mode that is deep and wide.
Let me expand on this point a bit. Being a leader in online travel and building an experienced marketplace isn't achieved by simply electronically connecting demand with supply. It may be a surprise to some, but about 2/3 of our employees are working on either the supply or customer service organizations. Only KAYAK, our 1 media asset, does not have a similar model. Our employees work at of 239 support offices in 173 cities around the world, working daily with partners and customers to deliver the absolute best booking experience wherever our customer comes from and wherever they're going.
On the supply side, we added over 200,000 properties during the year on Booking.com, covering everything from igloos to shared space, while maintaining stable take rates and a fee free model to the customer. Booking.com now has over 850 hotels -- 850,000 hotels, homes and other places to stay in over 220 countries and territories across the globe, up 34% from last year. The hard work of making this a daily really is achieved by thousands of dedicated and addicted energetic people around the world, having these properties and then working with our partners on an ongoing basis to ensure that our customers have the most choices of place to stay at the best prices available.
We offer by, far the most directly bookable lodging choices to our customers with over 22.6 million rooms potentially available on our websites, including 6.9 million rooms in vacation rentals and other non-hotel properties. With our worldwide team and market leading profitability, we are expanding this low-friction model more aggressively into the single owner, single room market as it continuous to mature. We strongly believe that this fee free experienced-centric model which makes booking homes and apartments as easy and trustworthy as booking a hotel, will be the winning model long-term.
On the customer experience side, the complexity of providing a world-class digital experience for customers becomes more daunting each year with various browsers and operating systems offered on desktop and mobile devices. On top of that, you have new platforms and capabilities being built every day. And for each of these, we need to make an intelligent decision about where and how to participate. The good news is the tools are becoming better, and customers continue to want to live more of their lives digitally. We have over 2,500 talented developers and other technology professionals working across our brands to offer our customers the best online booking experience on our desktop and mobile websites and app, optimize through hundreds of thousands of experiments.
We believe Booking.com has the highest converting online accommodation reservation path in the world, achieved through a deeply ingrained culture of innovation that results in experimentation at a transitional data scale and velocities that few companies can match. 
Our content this best-in-class with high resolution photos, detailed property descriptions, and 77 million plus verified and a fresh reviews for properties, in even the most far-flung destinations. We have thousands of customer service professionals stationed all over the world, helping our customers in 42 languages, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.  We think our approach adds up to a great experience for our customers, which helps us to continue to grow the direct share of our business with outstanding everyday pricing and repeat traffic versus the alternative, which is to buy the business with coupons or discounting transaction by transaction. 
Booking.com surpassed 100 million customer accounts during 2015, and had our 1 billion guests stayed at one of our partners, approximately 300 million of those in 2015 alone, another testament to our success at earning long-term loyalty.
We invested $3 billion in marketing during 2015 to build our brands around the world and bring new customers to our website at profitable ROIs. Our historical competitive strengths from the desktop have translated very well to mobile. Our talented team used proprietary quantitative tools to manage bidding on hundreds of millions of multilingual keywords across desktop and mobile platforms, successfully balancing ROI discipline with strong growth. We continue to command a leading share of the demand channels we participate in, profitably converting shoppers into buyers, and buyers into loyal long-term customers.
Every year is an investment year of The Priceline Group. While every year is also an opportunity to deliver outstanding bottom line results. We evaluate every opportunity with our long term lens, requiring that they deliver value for our brand franchise is still tomorrow, beyond just delivering transactions today. 2016 will be no different, as we invest in exciting new opportunities like OpenTable's international expansion, our BookingSuite cloud software offers, our Booking.com for Business, while maintaining superior operating margins that will allow us to win in the face of heated competition.
And you could be confident that we're not standing still. The Priceline Group will continue to work hard to stay a step ahead of the competition with our unique combination of institutional know-how, culture systems and focused passion. We don't take any competitor lightly, and we compete ferociously every day, continuously seeking a higher executional gear in every facet of our business.
Booking.com, of course, makes up the majority of our business. However, as the group also has a portfolio of valuable income commentary brands, each of which makes money and has the aspiration to grow and build vertical mastery in their respective area of focus. We have new leadership of priceline.com and OpenTable, and both businesses are responding with a renewed energy and a strong commitment to profitable growth.
Agoda and rentalcars.com both continued to improve and differentiate their respective products, and both look to drive more business direct and through improved mobile experiences. 
And finally, KAYAK is an outstanding business and that is being smartly run and continues to contribute to the group beyond our new initial expectation.
I give these other brand teams a lot of independence and this is in general performance culture. Through our portfolio of brands, we aspire to achieve the group's mission to help people experience the world and become a global marketplace for experiences. I thank my colleagues around the world for delivering another great year. Their skill and dedication has up to build a great business, with strong competitive advantages that have been responsible for our past success and will help us continue to succeed in the future.
I'll now turn the call over to Dan for the detailed financial review. Dan?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Darren. I'll discuss some of the highlights in operating results and cash flows for the quarter, and then provide guidance for the first quarter of 2016. All growth rates referenced in my comments are compared to the prior year comparable period,
componenttext:
Thanks, Darren. I'll discuss some of the highlights in operating results and cash flows for the quarter, and then provide guidance for the first quarter of 2016. All growth rates referenced in my comments are compared to the prior year comparable period, unless otherwise indicated. 
Q4 was a strong quarter for The Priceline Group, with accelerating room night growth and the second consecutive quarter of solid operating margin performance.  Growth was strong across all channels and geographic regions which we believe, indicates a generally healthy macro travel environment. 
Our global room night growth rate declined by more than 10 percentage points for a 2- to 3-week period after the terrorist attack in Paris, compared to what it had been before the attack. Growth bounced back strongly in December, and this momentum has carried over in Q1, as I will discuss further when I get to guidance.
Room nights booked grew by 27% in the fourth quarter, accelerating compared to the 22% growth rate for Q3. Rental car days grew by 11% in Q4 compared to Q3 growth of 13%. 
Average daily rates for accommodations, or ADRs, for Q4 2015 were up in a constant-currency basis by 1% for the consolidated group. Foreign exchange rates again presented a significant headwind into our growth rates expressed in U.S. dollars due to the strong dollar and to our business mix, which skews heavily internationally.
Our Q4 gross bookings grew by about 24% on a constant-currency basis, but by only about 13% expressed in U.S. dollars compared to prior year. International gross bookings grew by about 29% on a constant-currency basis and by 16% expressed in U.S. dollars.
Gross bookings for our U.S. business decreased by about 8%. We believe the U.S. performance was impacted by TV advertising decreases in the second half of 2015 as the priceline.com team transitioned their new brand campaign which recently launched in Q1. In addition, global airfares were down by about 15% over the last several months according to KAYAK Flight Search data, which significantly impacts priceline.com's gross bookings growth but has no impact on gross profit growth.
Gross profit for the quarter for The Priceline Group was $1.9 billion, and grew by about 23% on a constant-currency basis, and by 12% in U.S. dollars compared to prior year. Our gross profit take rates remain stable as they have been for quite some time now. We believe that our revenue margins have been and should continue to be sustainable due to our position as a relatively low-cost distribution channel that drives significant demand to our partners.
Our international operations generated gross profit of $1.6 billion, which grew by about 25% on a constant-currency basis, and by 12% in U.S. dollars compared to prior year. Gross profit for our U.S. operations amounted to $268 million, which represented 11% growth versus prior year. Advertising and other revenue, which is mainly comprised of KAYAK and OpenTable revenues, grew by 17% in Q4 compared to the prior year.
Operating margins exceeded our guidance and were similar to Q4 last year. Non-GAAP operating income amounted to 41.3% of gross profit for Q4 compared to 41.4% in Q4 last year. Online ad ROIs were better than our forecast but online advertising deleverage compared to the prior year due to the acceleration in gross bookings late in the quarter which will benefit revenue in Q1 and beyond when checkouts occur, as well as the impact of the terrorist attack on cancellations.
Off-line advertising came in slightly favorable to our forecast and is down year-over-year due to a shipment spent from off-line to online advertising for KAYAK, reduced advertising at priceline.com, as I mentioned a moment ago; and the impact of foreign exchange rates on Booking.com's off-line advertising expense, which grew by 18% in euros.
Non-advertising operating expenses were also favorable to our forecast and only generated 11 bps of margin pressure compared to prior year. Adjusted EBITDA for Q4 amounted to $790 million, which exceeded the top end of our guidance range of $760 million and grew by 11% versus prior year despite the significant negative foreign currency translation impact of the stronger U.S. dollar. 
Non-GAAP net income increased by 11%, and non-GAAP EPS grew by 16%, including interest expense from our recent bond offerings and the beneficial impact of lower share count from stock repurchases.
In terms of cash flow, we generated $881 million of cash from operations during fourth quarter 2015, which is about 17% above last year, and is also impacted by unfavorable foreign exchange rate translation. 
For the full year, we generated operating cash flow of $3.1 billion, and spent $174 million on CapEx, which means about 34% of our gross profit converted into free cash flow. We used our cash during the year to repurchase 2.5 million shares of our common stock for $3.1 billion. Darren just spoke about some of our operational competitive advantages. I believe that our market-leading profit margins, free cash flow, impeccable balance sheet and solid investment-grade credit rating, collectively constitute a competitive advantage because the significant financial flexibility to invest in our business to drive growth and positions us favorably versus our competitors.
Our board recently gave us a new authorization to repurchase up to $3 billion of our common stock. We expect to execute this program consistent with the pattern we've established over the last couple of years to return capital to shareholders at a pace that we think makes sense based on the price of which our stock is trading and potential others -- uses for such capital.
Our cash and investments amounted to $10.6 billion at December 31, 2015, with about $800 million of that balance in the U.S.
Now for Q1 guidance. Our quarter is off to a strong start, as I mentioned a moment ago. Some of the strength in December, and thus far in Q1, is likely attributable to Chinese New Year, Carnival and eastern happening earlier this year. Leap year also helps our forecast slightly relative to last year by adding an extra day to the quarter. Although we were very about macro weakness evident in slowing economic growth, dropping oil prices and stock market volatility, the macro travel environment appears healthy to us. 
Lower oil prices have contributed to the significantly lower airline ticket prices, and consumers with more discretionary funds that are available for travel. And lastly and most importantly, a combination of a strong core execution and the benefits of the number of growth investments we have been making, are helping to drive the group's success. And I sincerely thank my colleagues around the world for their efforts.
Our growth continues to be strong across all channels and regions. Our guidance assumes that our growth rates will decelerate as we progress through the quarter, maybe due to the size of our business and consistent with long-term trends. We are pleased with the brand marketing we get through TripAdvisor's Instant Book ad placement, but given the relative size of our business and our experienced so far, we don't expect that Instant Book will significantly impact our top line growth or ad efficiency.
Our Q1 forecast assumes foreign exchange rates of $1.12 per euro and $1.44 per British pound for the remainder of the quarter, which would result in average exchange rates that would be weaker by about 2% for the euro, and about 5% for the British pound as compared to the prior year.
Many other currencies in which we transact were also significantly weaker versus the U.S. dollar than they were in Q1 last year. As a result, our gross bookings, gross profit, operating expenses, adjusted EBITDA and non-GAAP net income will mathematically translate into fewer dollars than they would have at last year's exchange rates for Q1. 
As you can see in our guidance, the Q1 impact of currency fluctuations on our dollar reported figures while still meaningful, is less severe than what we experienced during 2015. Barring further deterioration in exchange rates, the year-over-year currency comps will become even less challenging after Q1. As I mentioned when we reported last quarter, we will no longer report U.S. gross bookings as a separate statistical metric. We believe that the usefulness of this metric has diminished out through the relative size of our priceline.com business to our consolidated results, and because our other 2 U.S. brands, KAYAK and OpenTable, do not have gross travel bookings. The metric also excludes the U.S. inbound, outbound and domestic business for Booking.com.
We will continue to report revenue and gross profit for our U.S. business as we have in the past to give insight into its performance. We were also adding guidance for consolidated room night growth to give visibility for this important metric. 
For Q1 guidance, we are forecasting book to room nights to grow by 20% to 27% and total gross bookings to grow by 18% to 25% on a constant-currency basis, and by 12% to 19% in U.S. dollars. Our Q1 forecast assumes that constant currency accommodation ADRs for the consolidated group will be up by about 1% compared to the prior year period. We expect Q1 revenue to grow year-over-year by approximately 9% to 16%. We expect gross profit to grow by 20% to 27% on a constant-currency basis, and by 14% to 21% in U.S. dollars.
We expect about 140 bps of deleverage in non-GAAP operating margins compared to prior year expressed as non-GAAP operating income as a percentage of gross profit. The deleverage is mainly attributable to our assumptions for online ad efficiency. 
Our online advertising efficiency forecast, as usual, assumes deterioration from current levels and provides us with flexibility in a dynamic market to follow our consistent approach of advertising our brands at reasonable ROIs.
Our adjusted EBITDA is expected to range between $580 million and $620 million, which at the midpoint, is an increase of 13% versus prior year. We estimate that the currency impact on EBITDA growth is similar to the impact that we are forecasting for gross profit.
Our non-GAAP EPS forecast includes an estimated cash income tax rate of approximately 16%, comprised of international income taxes and alternative minimum tax and state income taxes in the U.S. We are targeting non-GAAP fully diluted EPS of approximately $9 to $9.60 per share, which at the midpoint is an increase of 15% versus prior year. 
Our non-GAAP EPS guidance assumes a fully-diluted share count of 50.5 million shares based upon yesterday's closing stock price, and reflects the beneficial impact of the common stock repurchases we made in 2015. 
We forecast GAAP EPS between $6.90 and $7.50 per share for Q1. The difference between our GAAP and non-GAAP results is driven by non-GAAP adjustments that are detailed in our earnings release.
Consistent with past practice, we have hedged contracts in place to substantially shield our fourth quarter EBITDA and net earnings from any further fluctuation in the euro and British pound versus the dollar between now and the end of the quarter. The hedges did not offset the impact of translation on our gross bookings, revenue, gross profit or operating income. They also do not hedge us against fluctuations in other currencies, and do not hedge our earnings beyond the first [ph] quarter. Our forecast does not assume any significant change in macroeconomic conditions in general or in the travel market, in particular.
We will now take your questions.

componenttextpreview: Just 1 on the TripAdvisor Instant Booking, I think you said no, the impact contemplated in 2016. But was there any sort of discernible impact to the 4Q room night growth? And then just on your comments on take rates. It sounds like things are stable. I gu
componenttext: Just 1 on the TripAdvisor Instant Booking, I think you said no, the impact contemplated in 2016. But was there any sort of discernible impact to the 4Q room night growth? And then just on your comments on take rates. It sounds like things are stable. I guess -- I know this isn't a perfectly clean count, but if I look at gross profit growth kind of in an FX neutral basis, that would have kind of lagged room night growth a bit in the fourth quarter. So the first time and several quarters. Can you maybe just comment a bit on the drivers of the delta there if take rates are stable?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Tom, I'll take the first one on TripAssist, and I'll let Dan to take the second one. I think the -- one of the headlines of TripAssist is -- it's still very early. And as Steve will tell you, they're still rolling out the product. It's important to u
componenttext: Hey, Tom, I'll take the first one on TripAssist, and I'll let Dan to take the second one. I think the -- one of the headlines of TripAssist is -- it's still very early. And as Steve will tell you, they're still rolling out the product. It's important to understand the TripAdvisor makes up low single-digit percentage of our business. And TripAssist, within our TripAdvisor business, is a small percentage of our business. We have found or at least, we are happy with the brand impact, that was one of the reasons we did that. We are happy with the consumer behavior as we see it, but it's still small. And to be honest, if it becomes 2 or 3x the size it is today, it's still quite small for us from a materiality perspective. Again, we're happy with the execution -- the team has been connecting really well and we are curious to see how big it can become.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: On your second question, Tom, if you look at the gross bookings that you generated in Q4 and the take rate, the revenue that will ultimately generate from those, the rate is stable. So it's really just a booked versus stay difference. We typically see thi
componenttext: On your second question, Tom, if you look at the gross bookings that you generated in Q4 and the take rate, the revenue that will ultimately generate from those, the rate is stable. So it's really just a booked versus stay difference. We typically see this when we have a quarter room where we accelerate to the extent that we did, that due to the lag between with the booking occurs and the travel occurs, the growth in the gross profit typically lags that growth and gross bookings. And in particular, the strength at the end of the quarter last month will benefit through a greater extent Q1 and beyond, than in Q4.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe on OpenTable first. Congrats to Chris, as she stepped into that OpenTable CEO this quarter. You mentioned OpenTable international expansion in '16. Can you remind us on the countries they're in currently, and where you see opportunities for expansio
componenttext: Maybe on OpenTable first. Congrats to Chris, as she stepped into that OpenTable CEO this quarter. You mentioned OpenTable international expansion in '16. Can you remind us on the countries they're in currently, and where you see opportunities for expansion? And along the same lines, there are many players that are attacking that local reservation market on a global basis. How important are the relationships there versus, maybe having an all-encompassing platform with reviews, with reservations and maybe, even with delivery options -- or whether when come down to having the best attack and the best competitive rates?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Brian. Yes, as mentioned in my prepared remarks, we feel really good about where OpenTable is. We knew at the time we acquired it, that we've made how to make some changes in leadership. Chris has done an awesome job. The team hit all of its
componenttext: Okay, thanks, Brian. Yes, as mentioned in my prepared remarks, we feel really good about where OpenTable is. We knew at the time we acquired it, that we've made how to make some changes in leadership. Chris has done an awesome job. The team hit all of its Q4 KPIs, and these are all about have got -- how do we get medium- to long-term momentum. We are currently a prime and the United States but we also have operations in Japan, the U.K, Germany. And we've made an acquisition with AES digital to put us into Australia. There are also, by the way, a number of restaurants that use OpenTable software all around the world, although, may not have a consumer's facing site. The whole presence of globalizing OpenTable have been -- you see recently their latest app update allows Americans to book in London. You think that was the simplest thing that should've been done years ago, but there you go, it's done now. And this allows to become global. There's more things around languages as well. So if you go to book a restaurant in Germany, and you're from the United States, you will be able to see the menu in the product in English. And that's the kind of product that is going on platform and gets we expect that work to be done in this year than we have some amazing tools to be able to offer both the software proposition to restaurants as well as the demand proposition. But you'll see on Booking.com, for instance, if you search New York, you've got a beautifully little ad there, that says hey, book a restaurant in New York for OpenTable. Those things we found to be positive to the experiments. So that's where we are. I'm optimistic. I think ultimately, there is a traveler network effect. Our restaurants are a more local business than, say, hotel thong, of course. But on the other hand, transient travelers are extremely valuable to restaurants. I mean, filling those last few tables can also be the difference between making money and not making money. And they realize that those travelers have choice and they're relatively not near as informed as maybe local people and we think that's invaluable business. And we are seeing good results so far, but there's still a lot more work to do.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. Thanks, Naved. So there are really important math here is properties and rooms. And we talked about the 22.6 million rooms we have on our website. In Europe, we're actually still adding a lot of properties. But because this is our most mature m
componenttext: Yes, okay. Thanks, Naved. So there are really important math here is properties and rooms. And we talked about the 22.6 million rooms we have on our website. In Europe, we're actually still adding a lot of properties. But because this is our most mature market, those properties are becoming smaller and smaller. By the way, they're still tremendously valuable, because all of these of smaller properties adds tremendous diversity to our accommodation base. Therefore, they're being able to fit very specific needs. They also help us and low availability times. So if there's a conference or something, these properties can help fill demand when you're in a supply constrained environment. So Europe is -- a lot of properties that are getting smaller and smaller. And that's the nature of the European business. And frankly, in Italy, at a time, we're at adding 100 properties a day. Because these are very small properties in small places, kind of mom-and-pop operated type of product. In other parts of the world, we're still adding many large multiroom. I think India, China, in particular. China, we've gone -- enter the year with about 6,500 properties, exited the year with 35,000 properties. A lot of that was organically built. In China, they have a lot more to do in just adding really large hotels and properties. The challenge in China is making sure you have enough domestic demand to fill those. Inbound China is not a huge market, but domestic China is a huge market. And we're filling those beds there were no ships within China, including our relationship with Ctrip. Indian is another one that seems to have an ending potential for us, and we're busy there building out that marketplace. I'd say, another part of a world that -- Africa, Central America, these are the areas we're still adding hotels. But at some point, we will have a most of the world's hotels and then there's still a lot of extra property count in these single-owner, single apartment type product, almost endless to some degree, it seems. But we're having to add those -- our room/property at a time, and that's obviously important and tough work.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's really helpful. And then 1 follow-up. Earlier -- in your previous calls, Darren, you talked about how Europeans we're sort of more inclined to stay within Europe just because of maybe FX becoming somewhat of a headwind to travel abroad. What
componenttext: Okay, that's really helpful. And then 1 follow-up. Earlier -- in your previous calls, Darren, you talked about how Europeans we're sort of more inclined to stay within Europe just because of maybe FX becoming somewhat of a headwind to travel abroad. What kind of flaws are you seeing in terms of tourism or people are seeing within boundaries or not?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Naved. One -- there's 2 effects there we see with currency. There's -- one is the absolute level of the currency of the other issue is volatility. And the lower euro has a big impact but it's also the movement of the euro because people need
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Naved. One -- there's 2 effects there we see with currency. There's -- one is the absolute level of the currency of the other issue is volatility. And the lower euro has a big impact but it's also the movement of the euro because people need to get used to the fact that the euro is now $1.11 and no longer $1.35. So we certainly see no that the euro is stabilized and that's had a positive impact on a year-over-year base of European starting to travel back to America, started to travel to the U.K, starting to travel to higher currency zones. I think the other point that Dan made, the KAYAK date of the lights are down 15% year-over-year, that actually listen to the travel budget as well. So we're seeing more positive flows for -- of Europeans into these higher currency markets and certainly, hasn't certainly recovered to the time $1.35 a euro, but it's more positive than it was a year ago. That said, intra EU travel is still -- we're seeing very positive impacts there. There were -- there's a number of crises in the world -- Tunisia, Egypt, even Turkey. The positive there for us is that many of youths markets are wholesale kind of package travel markets. We have properties there but they're traditionally sort of the Thomas Cooks, the TUIs of the world and a lot of that travel is no ending up in Nativity in Spain and southern France and that's moreover, retail market that place also to our strength, and that's another trend that we've been seeing recently.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just 1 question. I know you aren't guiding beyond Q1, but on a high-level, how you're thinking about go forward operating margin trends as we lap the acquisitions, which could help nonadvertising operating leverage balance with dynamics of advertising
componenttext: And just 1 question. I know you aren't guiding beyond Q1, but on a high-level, how you're thinking about go forward operating margin trends as we lap the acquisitions, which could help nonadvertising operating leverage balance with dynamics of advertising ROIs and the related impact on advertising expense leverage or deleverage in 2016?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Mike. We don't guidance for you beyond Q1. But as we said in previous calls, we expect that we can have deliver operating leverage in the non-ad OpEx over time, with business going fast, it's a scalable. And so even with the investments that we're rem
componenttext: Hi, Mike. We don't guidance for you beyond Q1. But as we said in previous calls, we expect that we can have deliver operating leverage in the non-ad OpEx over time, with business going fast, it's a scalable. And so even with the investments that we're remaking to drive growth in the future, we think that we can deliver leverage there. Off-line advertising, we're going to heavy up in periods where we think we've got good creative, and it's moving video for us. But over the long term, we expect that we would have leverage there, too. It -- will it be a level in a market in both -- and hit the number of markets that we think we should be in, and then our business should continue to grow faster than our spend would. So then the biggest expense is also the biggest barrier, along that -- the online advertising. We are very pleased with what we've seen with the efficiency over the last couple of quarters, but we've had 3 years before that of seeing pressure on that metric and pressure on ROIs year-over-year. So it's difficult to predict what will happen there for the future, I have great confidence that we are probably better positioned than anybody else in the market with the most choices to try and convert that paid traffic into a booking on the best websites, the best converting websites from a desktop and mobile perspective, with the most clever advertising teams really tailoring our bidding approach and using best-in-class tools to make sure that we spend our money efficiently. So I like our competitive ham there. But I think that it's very difficult to predict exactly how that's going to play out in the future. But we have a good couple of good quarters in the books there.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me try 2 questions, please. Booking.com for Business, it's something that seems to be given at it for a while, but you maybe -- have emphasized it a little bit more this last 2 quarters, so could you talk about the growth strategy there and how materi
componenttext: Let me try 2 questions, please. Booking.com for Business, it's something that seems to be given at it for a while, but you maybe -- have emphasized it a little bit more this last 2 quarters, so could you talk about the growth strategy there and how material that is to business today? And then secondly, the China outbound market. I know you called out the Chinese New Year for Q1, and I know this is still a relatively small part of your business, but could you also talk about the materiality there, and anything unusually you're seeing in terms of the growth of that segment, particularly the China outbound market?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks. Thanks a lot, Mark. So Booking.com for Business, it's a -- it's worth just giving you a little background. So we are primarily the targeted lesion over time, we've seen more customers come in for business purposes, and that's when we started
componenttext: Okay. Thanks. Thanks a lot, Mark. So Booking.com for Business, it's a -- it's worth just giving you a little background. So we are primarily the targeted lesion over time, we've seen more customers come in for business purposes, and that's when we started to make some changes to our site, where we can see positive conversion, and that seems to work. So now you can go on to our site, they might be traveling for leisure or business. If you pick business, we highlight things important to businesspeople, and they seem to like that. And we've also discovered that about 20% of our business is business bookings versus leisure bookings. And the is of course is that -- we really knows but maybe half of travels business -- it could be more or less than that, but that points to a pretty big opportunity if we serve that customer well. So then secondly, we built a very simple tool that allows the systems to book for businesspeople, it allows you to track budget, it allows a manager to track where other people are, perspective. And now we're also optimizing that tool. We are seeing that our business bookings are growing faster than our leisure bookings, which means they are taking share on the site that's what we want to see. But it's a process of optimization and investment. And obviously, if you just think of the sheer size of the numbers that are going from 20 to 50, for instance, that's a huge opportunity but we're approaching it and in a very typical Booking.com Priceline Group, which is many small steps, lots of optimization and we're fairly positive. I think it will be one of the things that continues to contribute. There's no massive revolutionary movement, but more and evolutionary optimization. And today, feeling great about the progress but a lot more to do. Your second question, China outbound, some of it is hard to pick through when -- because of Chinese New Year, which is such a big holiday, and you guys have seen the pictures on the Internet and the train stations of -- hundreds of thousands of people. It was another great Chinese New Year, but the real question is where the things swing out. We did see, let's say, a little bit of softness, with China softness is all relative, it's still a fast-growing market, but still a little bit of softness in outbound and kind of Q3, Q4, a strong Chinese New Year. And then we have to see from there, where it goes. Obviously, the situation in China and the headlines can also rattle travelers. We haven't seen any large material effect. And I also believe, if my long-term thesis around China certainly hasn't changed, they are the world's largest outbound travelers, and we are going to continue to try to take a bigger share of that business going forward.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know chain hotels are a much smaller part of your mix, but Hilton, in particular, has been vocal over the last few months about ending last room night availability and pricing, and they now seem to be getting pretty aggressive in marketing their channel
componenttext: I know chain hotels are a much smaller part of your mix, but Hilton, in particular, has been vocal over the last few months about ending last room night availability and pricing, and they now seem to be getting pretty aggressive in marketing their channels against the OTAs. What do you believe is driving these efforts, and are you seeing any other change beginning to make similar moves?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Heath. Yes, as you point out, I mean, depending on where you call a chain, we -- about 10% to 15% of our business is combination of global and regional chains. And we're always in contract negotiations with the chains. In fact, our take rate
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Heath. Yes, as you point out, I mean, depending on where you call a chain, we -- about 10% to 15% of our business is combination of global and regional chains. And we're always in contract negotiations with the chains. In fact, our take rate is quite stable. With many chains, we never had last room availability. But over time, they've given us more availability, partly because of good business. We bring in a transient traveler, very few of our travelers to stay at the same hotel twice. And this is a valuable business because it's incremental. I think what you're seeing is discomfort with may be, with the world is changing but you should know our relationships are quite tight. There's also a difference between the chain and the owner of the hotel. I mean, the owner of the hotel wants more of this kind of business. And most of them want to lean into our model. For me, the average chain hotel only gets about 1/2 of the business that should be coming to us, partly because of all of these restrictions that are put on it. But many chain owners are also agitating to make sure they get their fair share because the business they're not getting is either going to another chain or it's going through an independent hotel. So yes, I don't appreciate some of the actions that they've taken at the same level at times, but our relationships on a day-to-day basis are actually quite constructive and cordial. And our chain business is actually quite healthy. They have great products. Our customers want the product. And most of our customers, when they come to Washington, D.C, for instance, they're not looking for the Hilton or the Marriott in Washington. They're looking for a great bed in Washington. And our ranking system presents to them, this is well priced. And if the product is not well priced, or it's not available, it's not going to convert and therefore, it won't be presented to the customer. That's basically the way it works and I'm always hopeful we can work through many of these issues when they arise.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Darren, maybe you could comment a little bit about your philosophy on vacation rentals charging the owner as opposed to the renter? Obviously, one of your competitors is going through a transition, why you like that business model? And then Dan, could you
componenttext: Darren, maybe you could comment a little bit about your philosophy on vacation rentals charging the owner as opposed to the renter? Obviously, one of your competitors is going through a transition, why you like that business model? And then Dan, could you quantify at all, the Paris impact in Q4 and maybe the Easter impact in Q1? And then Europe really had some good RevPAR over the summer last year. I know you won't guide 2Q or 3Q but how do you think about those comps in Europe as you approach this summer?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Justin. Our model -- part of the reason we get to our model is we default to it. That's the way our entire business works. And -- but if you look at our take rate in vacation rentals, where we are charging the vacation rental owner and HomeAw
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Justin. Our model -- part of the reason we get to our model is we default to it. That's the way our entire business works. And -- but if you look at our take rate in vacation rentals, where we are charging the vacation rental owner and HomeAway or Airbnb, we'll charge a lot to the consumer. The takes rates are actually quite a equivalent when you look at the total take rate. I think anyone with charge to the owner but if you don't have been instantly verifiable deal, then you might be a word nerd first ever showed up, or he didn't stay or we didn't close the transaction. So we're actually in an enviable position to be able to do the way we do. Obviously, I don't -- I only met a consumer who only likes to pay fees. And we're betting that, that consumers won't want to pay fees. But more importantly, what we're trying to do is make booking a vacation rental or a home or an apartment as easy as booking a hotel room, with the same level of trust, with the same feeling like you're going to get what you paid for. There's no post-negotiation on price, which happens sometimes on a non-request model. There's no post-negotiation. Maybe, I want you to stay -- or actually, my room's not available right now. And I believe that is where our model will ultimately end up, getting from where we are today to where we need to, there's certainly, still a lot of friction. But we're finding pretty positive response to this model and it's also, I think is a nice way to set expectations with both the booker and the place that they're booking. And so we're sticking with that model, it seems to be working for us. But still, a lot of work to do but we're playing set of a long game here that I think more experienced-centric friction-free model are the future versus what -- how the business is being done today.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the near us the other question, Justin, so Paris impact, I did say in my prepared remarks that we saw about 2 or 3 weeks after the attack there are global room night growth rate dropped by more than 10 percentage points. And that was a combination of l
componenttext: In the near us the other question, Justin, so Paris impact, I did say in my prepared remarks that we saw about 2 or 3 weeks after the attack there are global room night growth rate dropped by more than 10 percentage points. And that was a combination of less people booking and significant increase in cancellations of bookings that were already in our system. But then such a solid bounce back in December and such a great quarter overall, from a top line and bottom line perspective that we didn't go and try to quantify any kind of an EBITDA impact to report to you. I don't feel like there's really anything to explain there. So I feel good with a quarter that we delivered despite the impact. For Easter, we don't have a number there are either and there's a lot of travel that happens right around Easter, and we expect that, that will move from Q2 last year into Q1. But there are other breaks that people get that are just kind of around the time of Easter or I know from Mike's -- our break is still going to be in April this year, so I don't know that we could precisely quantify for you the exact impact there. But it is beneficial to revenue in Q1. It would be a little bit of a detrimental revenue in Q2. From a gross profit perspective -- sorry, gross bookings perspective, it's probably a little bit negative to Q1 and that during that period, where people are traveling, the bookings really drop off to a lower level because they're not booking while they're traveling. So that is the way to think about that intensive gross bookings. And then summer comps, yes, it was a very strong summer season for us. It's too early to predict now. We're not giving getting's for summer, but we said that our prepared remarks, we feel pretty good about the macro-travel environment right now, and hope that will continue into the summer and -- paired with lower fuel prices, lower airline ticket prices, hopefully, mean strong -- some good tailwinds for summer travel.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back, Dan, to the comments kind of post Paris and the 10 points of impact that you mentioned. And just in particular, was there something that you can point out, that drove such a strong bounce back in terms of business, and was there
componenttext: I just wanted to go back, Dan, to the comments kind of post Paris and the 10 points of impact that you mentioned. And just in particular, was there something that you can point out, that drove such a strong bounce back in terms of business, and was there anything that you guys did, marketing or promotion wise that really contributed there? And then secondly, if you can give us an update on the BookingSuite business as well?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so in terms of the Paris, there was nothing -- I mean, our approach with advertising day in and day out is very consistent. So we're looking to generate as much business as we can at a reasonable ROI, and we didn't change anything that caused the traj
componenttext: And so in terms of the Paris, there was nothing -- I mean, our approach with advertising day in and day out is very consistent. So we're looking to generate as much business as we can at a reasonable ROI, and we didn't change anything that caused the trajectory of the business to change that was consistent. And I think just amazing, the resilience of people that even how horrific event, like those in attacks in Paris, in a relatively short amount of time, people became comfortable again with the idea of traveling. Paris still is impacted where it was pre-attire for us and as a share of our business but has bounced back from where it was. And so I think we benefit also from being a global player with so many different choices where people can travel to. But if they're not comfortable with the particular destination, they can find other places where they may feel more comfortable with traveling. So really, just the resilience would be the one thing that we'd point to that -- thank God there were no additional attacks and so the business bounced back.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on BookingSuite, we feel really good about the business. We don't have any numbers to share, just for competitive reasons. But we've built up the team. We added a new product, PriceMatch. It's a revenue management cloud-based tool in 2015, w
componenttext: And then just on BookingSuite, we feel really good about the business. We don't have any numbers to share, just for competitive reasons. But we've built up the team. We added a new product, PriceMatch. It's a revenue management cloud-based tool in 2015, which has been a nice addition. But generally, the demand for the product was very high and it's been an issue -- how do we feel fulfilled the demand for the team but I'm proud of where it's at. And we hope 2016 will be another big year for BookingSuite.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ken Sena with Evercore Partners.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ken Sena with Evercore Partners.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you maybe, just in terms of the bookings acceleration, talk a little bit more, maybe about the vacation rental contribution and maybe the opportunity there -- and then anything on the hotel room night also? And then you mentioned that TripAdvisor wo
componenttext: Could you maybe, just in terms of the bookings acceleration, talk a little bit more, maybe about the vacation rental contribution and maybe the opportunity there -- and then anything on the hotel room night also? And then you mentioned that TripAdvisor won't be a significant -- it won't offer a significant impact to the top line, or ad efficiencies, so maybe can you expand on that a bit from a branding standpoint, how satisfied you are with a partnership right now where the product?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think I can take both of us, Ken. Well, yes, on the -- on vacation rentals generally, and I would say, self-catered products as well, is what we call -- and this includes apartments and homes and aparthotels. That's a -- that part of the market ha
componenttext: Okay. I think I can take both of us, Ken. Well, yes, on the -- on vacation rentals generally, and I would say, self-catered products as well, is what we call -- and this includes apartments and homes and aparthotels. That's a -- that part of the market has traditionally has a lot more friction in it than the hotel booking side. And as that section gets removed, you can begin to see growth. Certainly, there's the sort of Airbnb effect of this being a new way to travel. But more importantly, our large groups, families, booking a self-catered product, actually really good deal or present value equation looks good but all kinds of fiction around, is it going to be there? Where does my money go? They wanted the closet, et cetera, et cetera -- as we remove those points of fiction we are seeing the growth in that area. i don't have any numbers to share, but that space is faster than our core business, which is what you would hope. And we feel like we have plenty of demand as we get ready to supply -- to fill those rooms with guests who are looking for them. The other question was on Instant Book. Yes, it's still very early days, but we're happy with the way that TripAdvisor has fulfilled their side of the deal. The branding looks great. It seems to -- particularly, in the U.S. market where the early rollout has been, where the Booking.com brand is not a strong, I think that's helped us a lot. They're now rolling out in some markets may be where we're stronger, maybe will help them a bit, where our brand might even be stronger than TripAdvisor. But I think from a mutual perspective, it's been positive. There's a lot yet to optimize, but we sort of think about it as -- well, we've got an ad, and we have a performance tool to drive more business. And that's always a real positive thing to the company. I'm still, by the way, optimistic, still very supportive. And let's see where things end up as Steven and his team gets to roll this product up to more markets.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two, if I can. First, just there's been a lot of changes in REIT parity regulations in France and Germany, and I'm wondering if you guys are seeing in the discernible trend and how hotels in France may be responding to the law, how it's impacting conversi
componenttext: Two, if I can. First, just there's been a lot of changes in REIT parity regulations in France and Germany, and I'm wondering if you guys are seeing in the discernible trend and how hotels in France may be responding to the law, how it's impacting conversion, and kind of of how you think this ultimately plays out in the EU? And then second question -- similar, the Innovation Box Tax regime in the Netherlands. It seems like it's in a bit of flux. Can you just give us kind of a sense of how much of your pretax income flows through with the reduced tax rate, how you think either rates or the magnitude of the shield, are likely to change over the next few years, or perhaps, maybe grandfathering gives you a long period of time before you see this, any comments on these -- either of those?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll take the first one, Dan, you take the second. Well, we haven't seen any major impacts but it's been a great experimental bid. And I think one of the biggest learnings and I had mentioned in the previous comments is, customers aren't going to ov
componenttext: Okay. I'll take the first one, Dan, you take the second. Well, we haven't seen any major impacts but it's been a great experimental bid. And I think one of the biggest learnings and I had mentioned in the previous comments is, customers aren't going to overpay for a product. So if the properties are free to price the product the way they want to price it, but if it's overpriced, then it won't convert, and then they don't get any business. So in a way, the marketplace has a self-actualization to it, regardless of what the rules are. We still believe parity is a very important construct. We think it frankly offers a lot of opportunity also for the properties to have a level playing field so that we're not using our margins, undercut them. But I'm now comfortable with any regime, that people realize if they want to get bookings on Booking, you have to have a well-priced product and the marketplace deals with that. And if you don't, then nothing sales, conversion goes down, your ranking goes down. And then you don't get any business. So it's been interesting. All of our checks would say that parity in France is at least, if not more healthy, than most of our markets in the world. And I think that's overall, a good news.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Lloyd, on your second question, innovation box, the 10K will be held shortly and -- quantifies that exactly. So I don't know I'm going to leave it through that 10-K to take care of that one for you. It's a significant benefit for us as you point out.
componenttext: And Lloyd, on your second question, innovation box, the 10K will be held shortly and -- quantifies that exactly. So I don't know I'm going to leave it through that 10-K to take care of that one for you. It's a significant benefit for us as you point out. We have a risk factor in our 10-K that'll also point you to the clearly delineates what we see is the risks related to the innovation box. We need to continue to qualify as being innovative, and we need to receive extensions from the Dutch tax authorities. We've done well with that since the advent of the innovation box. So I feel confident there. And then there's also developments at the OECD, the organization of the economic cooperation and development, where they're looking to harmonize tax treatment across European Union and. One of the things that they are taking into consideration is these innovation box type regimes. And they've talked about during doing away with them sometime in 2021. So that's certainly risked out there. 2021 is still a long long way away and tax are subject to change, rates could change and the OECD's interpretations could change. So those are the things that you should look to and again, I would refer you to the specific wording in the 10-K.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Peter from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from Peter from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple quick ones. First, regarding the bidding program that allows your hotel partners to improve their ranking in the results, I'm wondering if you could comment on the uptake you're seeing for that in the market? And is participation large enough her
componenttext: A couple quick ones. First, regarding the bidding program that allows your hotel partners to improve their ranking in the results, I'm wondering if you could comment on the uptake you're seeing for that in the market? And is participation large enough here to impact the blended take rates, or is it really a kind of nonmaterial service offering that you are presenting to the market? And then secondly, quickly, any expectation for negative impact due to Zika virus here?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, Peter, so the first one, I'll take. I think, first of all, it's important to understand how the ranking algorithm works. The primary driver of helping the rank is conversion, so it really is consumer interest. And you always have to be very ca
componenttext: Okay. Okay, Peter, so the first one, I'll take. I think, first of all, it's important to understand how the ranking algorithm works. The primary driver of helping the rank is conversion, so it really is consumer interest. And you always have to be very careful in how you balance monetization with consumer interest. Because if you overweighed on monetization, you could never really, the results and no one wants to come to your website. So at least the way we've done it in the past is we have standard hotels the preferred hotels. And preferred hotels are only allowed to become preferred if they meet a number of experienced criteria. And then they have slightly higher commission, and can often as much, doubled their bookings by being preferred. That's been our primary driver. The second one that we do allow some overrides. They're not used broadly, but in the hotel can pay more commission if they want, stay at a new hotel they don't have a lot of reviews or something, to try and get a slightly higher ranking, but it's never -- we never allow them ultimately, to buy the very top of the ranking from the very bottom. It doesn't work that way. So we feel comfortable with the model that we have. I think it's a very -- like in any auction site, you have to really be careful with the diode, because you think you might win the monetization but if you crop of the product, then you're not going to have any customers. So that's the way I think about it. And your next question was -- Dan, why don't you take the Zika?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Zika virus, Peter, thus far, we haven't seen a significant impact. Most of the travel within southern hemisphere is from other destinations in southern hemisphere, so it's generally people traveling from an area that's been impacted to another are
componenttext: Yes. So Zika virus, Peter, thus far, we haven't seen a significant impact. Most of the travel within southern hemisphere is from other destinations in southern hemisphere, so it's generally people traveling from an area that's been impacted to another area that's impacted. And so we haven't seen that's deterring during travel. We don't want to predict what the impact could be for the future, but that's been the impact up-to-date.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This concludes that Q&A session I'll now turn the call back over to Darren Huston.
componenttext: This concludes that Q&A session I'll now turn the call back over to Darren Huston.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I guess, just in conclusion, we were really pleased with the quarter. I hope you are. It's nice to enter the year we were growing faster than we rented the year in our size and scale, we always are facing a lot large numbers. But a big thanks t
componenttext: Yes, well, I guess, just in conclusion, we were really pleased with the quarter. I hope you are. It's nice to enter the year we were growing faster than we rented the year in our size and scale, we always are facing a lot large numbers. But a big thanks to all of our people and mostly just great execution and seen a lot of growth initiatives began to pay off. Is a great feeling. Thanks, all, for joining the call and we'll see you next quarter.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
